definition: to capture a prisoner/to take sb captive

sentences.english: The dancer took everybody at the performance by storm.
sentences.chinese: 这名舞者的表演掳获每个人的心。

sentences.english: In 68 attacks they have captured only 18 ships, often small ones.
sentences.chinese: 目前68起攻击，只掳获18艘小型的船舶。

sentences.english: In captivity, two years is the average span.
sentences.chinese: 被人掳获的平均寿命为两年。

sentences.english: Expression in your eyes, capture all my attentions.
sentences.chinese: 你的眼神，掳获我的全部注意。

sentences.english: Read on to learn more about this enchanting country that has captivated the world's imagination for so long.
sentences.chinese: 往下读，深入了解掳获长期世人想像空间的迷人国度。

definition: to capture (enemy property or personnel)/capture (physics: absorption of subatomic particle by an atom or nucleus)
to win the support of/to get over to one's side/to keep control of
as easy as blowing off dust/effortless/with ease
pinyin: bu4 fei4 chui1 hui1 zhi1 li4

definition: to defeat/to overpower/to beat/to be defeated
to instigate (rebellion etc)/incitement (e.g. to desertion within opposing camp)
to become suddenly popular/suddenly all the rage
to change sides in a war/turncoat
